sub_title: Professor of Social Epidemiology at Maastricht University
summary:
I am a professor in the field of socioeconomic and psychosocial determinants of poor health outcomes. With a background in sociology and methodology (graduated in 1989), I have a longtime interest in social inequalities. I have an advanced experience in and knowledge of large-scale longitudinal research with state-of-the-art methodologies. 

My PhD thesis, using data from one of the first large-scale epidemiological studies in both The Netherlands and Lithuania (then under Soviet reign), reports on socioeconomic and psychosocial risk factors of coronary heart disease. 

After my PhD thesis (1994), I broadened my experience with longitudinal research at Statistics Netherlands where I looked at inequalities in educational careers. 

Between 1995 and 1999, I worked at the two prestigious research institutes in the field of socioeconomic inequalities in health: Professor Marmot’s group in London and Professor Mackenbach’s group in Rotterdam. In these workplaces, I studied job control and psychological characteristics in their relation to health inequalities.

Working at the Neuropsychology department at the Maastricht Unviersity, I extended my experiences by studying cognitive and successful aging, with a particular focus on social determinants. 

In 2001, I joined the group of Medical Sociology (later Social Medicine), where I have been involved in both supervision of PhD students in the field of public health and education (social medicine internships and public health). I have been a program leader and a vice chair of one of the research programs of research school CAPHRI. 

I published several times in The Lancet and the British Medical Journal, as well as in other high-impact journals in the field of public health and social medicine (e.g. American Journal of Public Health and American Journal of Epidemiology). I am an associate editor for Social Science & Medicine, International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, BMC Public Health, and BMC Research Notes.

projects.title: Stay In Or Drop Out (SIODO)
projects.description: School dropout is a major issue in the Netherlands. Which health factors play a role? And how do intersections across socioeconomic status and gender affect school dropout? In this study, we aim to gain more insight in these aspects in order to help solve this problem.
